title: Motion sensor lab - cart down an incline

content.question: In an experiment, students roll a cart down an inclined plane of negligible friction. The students determined that the cart’s mass is <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the angle of the inclined plane is <math alttext="30 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal. The students use a motion detector to record the acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cart as a function of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The data are shown in the graph. One student states that the collected data is not valid. Which of the following could be a valid explanation for the flawed data?

choices.label: There is friction acting on the cart, reducing the acceleration from what was expected.
The incline is at an angle greater than <math alttext="30 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, increasing the acceleration from what was expected.

The cart has a mass greater than <math alttext="0.5 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, increasing the acceleration from what was expected.
The surface of the inclined track is not uniform, creating fluctuations in the acceleration as seen with the bumpy line.
The student is incorrect. The data shown are accurate for the information given.

content.answer: The incline is at an angle greater than <math alttext="30 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, increasing the acceleration from what was expected.
